commentBody: Here's an an interesting idea for Democrats to ponder: Suppose Trump is impeached and then Pelosi did NOT immediately send the case to the Senate, but instead declared it would be wrong to hold a trial in a hot election year, but that it could be picked up later. Of course, Trump would yell bloody murder about his "right" to a speedy trial but no such right exists, and besides, didn't McConnell invoke the same in the Merrick Garland case? This would leave Trump twisting in the wind while the Dems pursued their winning kitchen table agenda. Of course, a Democratic victory would make the case moot while a Democratic defeat would still leave the option open to try and remove him. Your thoughts?
replies:
[{'commentID': 103926143, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103926143, 'userID': 59017893, 'userDisplayName': 'lynchburglady', 'userLocation': 'Oregon', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': "@Jay S 
Interesting idea, but this thought occurred to me...What if, horrors of horrors, Trump is somehow elected again?  We would also have a new Senate and a new House.  Would the articles of impeachment carry over to that new House?  Or would they have to start over again at the beginning?  If both the House and Senate wind up being held by the Democrats, fine, Trump is history.  But what if they don't?  For the life of me I simply cannot understand why this man is still our president...he has flouted just about every law on the books and done it in plain sight.  He has thumbed his nose at our Constitution and gotten away with it.  Apparently, the Republicans are afraid of his base...why?  Are they afraid that the base will literally use that 2nd Amendment solution Trump so cheerfully suggested be used against Hillary?  Or are they afraid that they will lose votes?  The Republican base will never ever vote Democratic, so no worries there.  What are they so afraid of?  There is absolutely no reason that I can think of for Trump to still be in the White House...and yet he is.", 'createDate': '1575305103', 'updateDate': '1575537395', 'approveDate': '1575306298', 'recommendations': 11, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103924763, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Jay S', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103926143', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103925424, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103925424, 'userID': 46900727, 'userDisplayName': 'Ken', 'userLocation': 'MT Vernon, NH', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Jay S 

There is no way Democrats can afford a trial in the Senate. 

Republicans will call witnesses that belie the sham.

Call it the McConnell doctrine! (LEH!)
Another possibility;
Trump wins, but the D hold the house and retake the Senate. This opens the possibility of a good majority voting to remove, though probably not a supermajority.

But your idea of simply leaving it dangling out there will drive the boy nuttier and nuttier. If nothing else it would be hilarious.", 'createDate': '1575301910', 'updateDate': '1575537435', 'approveDate': '1575308015', 'recommendations': 13, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103924763, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Jay S', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103925182', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103928205, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103928205, 'userID': 58678784, 'userDisplayName': 'James Miller', 'userLocation': 'Earlysville, Virginia', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': "@Jay S 

If, after losing the 2020 election Trump makes noises about refusing to recognize the result and says he'll hang on in the White House, it might be necessary to hold the impeachment trial before January 20, 2021. Would the existing--but not yet acted upon--articles of impeachment still be valid for an incoming new Democratic Congress to act on? Or would the new Congress have to re-pass the articles? But if Trump were trying to ignore his electoral defeat and insist that he was still the rightful president, a quick new impeachment trial might be important leverage in trying to oust him.

We certainly are in uncharted waters, aren't we? Who knows whether we'll survive all this.", 'createDate': '1575311927', 'updateDate': '1575384232', 'approveDate': '1575314345', 'recommendations': 3, 'replyCount': 0, 'replies': [], 'editorsSelection': False, 'parentID': 103924763, 'parentUserDisplayName': 'Jay S', 'depth': 2, 'commentType': 'userReply', 'trusted': 0, 'recommendedFlag': 0, 'permID': '103928205', 'isAnonymous': False}, {'commentID': 103928917, 'status': 'approved', 'commentSequence': 103928917, 'userID': 67780436, 'userDisplayName': 'Dan', 'userLocation': 'Lafayette', 'userTitle': 'NULL', 'userURL': 'NULL', 'picURL': None, 'commentTitle': '<br\//>', 'commentBody': '@Ken
